scenarios: Generated Case 1: [Process_Auditor] 6yo male with supracondylar fracture from falling off a swing, pink pulseless hand, arrived Saturday 20:00, surgery Sunday 09:00 (13h delay), Borderline.
Generated Case 2: [Preventability_Detective] 7-year-old female with supracondylar fracture due to skateboard accident, AIN palsy, arrived Sunday 15:30, surgery Sunday 18:00 (2.5h delay), Clear Pass.
Generated Case 3: [Delay_Driver_Profiler] 5yo male with supracondylar fracture from monkey bars fall, pucker sign, arrived Friday 17:00, surgery Saturday 11:00 (18h delay), Clear Fail.
Generated Case 4: [Exclusion_Hunter] 9yo female with supracondylar fracture from bicycle crash, compartment syndrome, arrived Saturday 14:00, surgery Saturday 16:00 (2h delay), Clear Pass.

Generated Case 5: [Safety_Signal] 4-year-old male with supracondylar fracture from trampoline accident, normal neurovascular status, arrived Saturday 12:00, surgery Saturday 14:00 (2h delay), Clear Pass.

test_cases.description: 6yo male with supracondylar fracture, pink pulseless hand, borderline timing.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 6-year-old male presented to the emergency department after falling off a swing. On examination, he was found to have a Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture with a pink pulseless hand. He arrived at the hospital on Saturday at 20:00 and was taken to surgery the next day at 09:00, resulting in a total delay of 13 hours. The clinical team was concerned about the neurovascular status due to the pulselessness of the hand, which was addressed prior to the operation.

must_find_signals: Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture

test_cases.description: 7-year-old female with supracondylar fracture, AIN palsy, clear pass.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 7-year-old female was brought to the emergency department after a skateboard accident that resulted in a Gartland type II supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon evaluation, she exhibited signs of anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) palsy. She arrived at the hospital on Sunday at 15:30 and underwent surgery at 18:00 the same day, leading to a delay of only 2.5 hours. The surgical team was able to address the injury promptly, ensuring optimal recovery.

must_find_signals: Gartland type II supracondylar humerus fracture

test_cases.description: 5yo male with supracondylar fracture, pucker sign, clear fail.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 5-year-old male child presented to the emergency department after falling from the monkey bars. He was diagnosed with a Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture and exhibited a positive pucker sign. The patient arrived on Friday at 17:00 but was not taken to surgery until Saturday at 11:00, resulting in an 18-hour delay. Despite the significant delay, the surgical team was concerned about the potential for compartment syndrome and acted accordingly once in the OR.

must_find_signals: Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture

test_cases.description: 9yo female with supracondylar fracture, compartment syndrome, clear pass.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 9-year-old female sustained a Gartland type II supracondylar humerus fracture in a bicycle crash. Upon arrival at the emergency department at 14:00 on Saturday, she demonstrated signs of compartment syndrome. She was evaluated quickly and taken to surgery at 16:00 the same day, resulting in a 2-hour delay. The surgical team prioritized her case due to the urgent nature of her condition, ensuring timely intervention.

must_find_signals: Gartland type II supracondylar humerus fracture

test_cases.description: 4yo male with supracondylar fracture, normal neurovascular status, clear pass.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 4-year-old male experienced a Gartland type I supracondylar humerus fracture after a trampoline accident. He arrived at the emergency department on Saturday at 12:00 and underwent surgery at 14:00, leading to a delay of 2 hours. Upon examination, he was found to have normal neurovascular status, allowing for a straightforward surgical intervention. The team was pleased with the timely management of this case.

must_find_signals: Gartland type I supracondylar humerus fracture
